Award.AwardTitle: IUSE: Exploration of Journaling to Assess Design Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) project will help enhance the ability of undergraduate engineering students to develop and document their new ideas during the design process and will also help engineering faculty to assess and evaluate the ability of students to generate and develop design ideas. In the United States the development of new inventions is considered a critical element in creating new industries and jobs, thus improving local and national economies. However, at present, engineering education does not have well-recognized methods to measure student ideation ability. Scores from regular course homework and exams which comprise a traditional assessment of ideation learning are not strongly linked to competence in generating and developing ideas for engineering designs. The project focuses on development of design journaling practices as a means to improve idea generation ability in the context of engineering design projects. Methods and metrics through which faculty can analyze and evaluate design journal entries will also be developed.

Design journalizing is generally recognized as an effective method to develop and record ideas related to the development of technological artifacts and systems. Many celebrated inventors throughout history maintained extensive and detailed design journals. However, engineering students today are generally disinclined to engage in effective journaling during design projects. This work will help to develop design journaling practices that engage students and provide effective learning experiences. In addition, journaling assessment practices will be developed so that design instructors can provide timely and effective design feedback and input, especially during the ideation process. The research questions examined in this project include: in what ways can journaling be used in design courses to effectively assess individual ideation performance and learning in both individual and team design scenarios; how do design journal entries reflect the level of design engagement for an individual during a team ideation process; and do variations such as different learning style approaches predict variations in student journaling behavior in a design course? Design is a universal skill needed by engineers and the results from this project will improve the ability of students to create and document designs and faculty ability to assess design learning. The project includes efforts to communicate the results of this work to the broader engineering education community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Design Teams are the major source of innovative products and successful application of new technology. Understanding of successful design behavior is important to improving the education of engineering students, individually, and in teams. Results from design work are available for review in the form of product specifications, drawings, prototypes, analysis reports, part lists, manufacturing instructions, quality measures, and all other information about the product and its development. This product information represents knowledge for future design work. However, this cache of product knowledge does not include what the designers were thinking and how key design decisions were taken.

The part of the design process with the fewest records is the beginning of design when the initial concepts for products are created. Creating the best set of concepts is critical to quality products. This is also the time when inventive ideas are conceived. Knowledge of concept generation is the most elusive of all design knowledge. At the same time, it is valuable to the education of new engineers.

This study gained insight into the thoughts of mechanical engineering design students during the final design course prior to their graduation. Volunteer students kept contemporaneous notes of their thoughts and work during the design process. We do not know what activity is taking place in the minds of the students, but we can assume that the are recording what they are thinking in the act of writing.  

Eighty-three (83) student design journals were analyzed in this study. The journal pages were coded for type of content. The design content fell into 8 major categories: Information Seeking & Noting, Problem Understanding, Idea Generation, Analysis, Decisions, Project Management. Reflection, and Other. The journals averaged 179 codable sections each, the range of segments was about 100 to 503 segments per journal. The type and timing of each journal segment was recorded. Statistical analysis determined that the number of journal segments did not change the relative frequency of design content entries. This means that journals can be studied as a group regardless if the student had more or less than the average number of entries. This supports the use of student design journals as a method of research on design behavior. Several outcomes on individual design behavior were found.

  • Analysis entries would be more frequent than Idea Generation. For many students, Analysis was the most frequently recorded activity class. However, students who recorded Analysis activity were less likely to report Information Seeking & Noting, Project Management or Reflection.
  • Many student journals displayed a high degree of specialization in design certain. This raises the question, "How much individual learning is desired in capstone design courses?"
  • Frequency of recordings activities changed during the semester long project. Less abstract thought was required periods occurring after the final concept was determined.
  • Specialization of individual is evident in the data.

The study data included journals from students of 17 teams. This journal content was combined to examine the design behavior of a team as if it were one individual. Rough comparisons indicated that the relative frequency of activities of a design team is not different than that of an individual.

  • Student references their team?s final concept is 40.1% of the times they referenced any concept on average. This metric could be developed to indicate how much of the journal is spent working on the final concept.
  • There are different styles of team activities when viewed by combining the records of individuals. A natural inquiry is how the roles of the team members emerge. Are they natural? Are roles assigned? Is this a function of team leadership?

The findings from this initial analysis of the data provide descriptive statistics on key student and team behaviors. Other significant analyses can be done. Are there gender differences in design activities on a team? Can a journal metric be found that will reflect the level of individual engagement with the team design process? What type of team style is best for design? Can a level of specialization in student activity be reached without sacrificing individual learning outcomes? How are the roles of the team members determined?

Answering questions posed by the outcomes of this work is beyond the skill stet of engineering design researchers alone. Partnerships with cognitive researchers in psychology and education are needed. The coded journals also represent an opportunity for content analysis on a variety of questions.

In conclusion, this study exceeded the research team?s expectation by finding expected and unexpected results on student behavior during design. The research has suggested many fascinating directions for future work, much of it based on the body of collected data.
